number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												General - 8.0Sid Meier's Civilization is one of the greatest game franchises ever, it's a landmark for every turn-based strategy game. The name itself tells what the game is about, you pick one civilization, select a location to start, select CPU controlled civilizations and settings for that specific map. Your job is to make your civilization meet any of the victory conditions, which can be through science, military, culture, diplomacy, points, etc. The first game of the series I played was Civ II, back in 2001, which instantly made me a fan since then. However I skipped Civ III at its time, and that is what made me buy it many years later. I paid around 1USD for the game just to see what I missed, and unfortunately, not much. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game, but if you played Civ IV, in my opinion, there is nothing in Civ III that will be better than in the later game. It's only worth playing for saudosism purposes. It's heavily outdated.Content - 8.5Steam version is a complete version, which includes both expansion packs released. You have a vast number of civilizations to pick and you can adjust some major settings for a location, like temperature, umidity, geological era, water level, etc. You can also chose the victory conditions for a game, which you can fit into your play style, along with difficulty level. The Civilopedia is a tool of great educational value, it contains real data about the civilizations, technologies, unities and almost everything you can find in the game. There is a highest scores table too, but I believe it only displays single-player scores. I don't know if steam is providing some sort of multiplayer support at this time.Gameplay - 4.0Like most Civ games, you start with a settler, a worker and/or a warrior in most cases, from this you have to build your city and administer it's growth with the resources gathered around it, which can be selected in the city radius. Each unity you create in a city has a better use, and through the years (turns), as long as your cities and citizens are productive you'll eventually discover technologies which improve your unities and your cities buildings. You can focus your whole civilization in a few aspects or diversify your knowledge. Every civilization on the map have it's own personality and choices, from warmongers to pacifists. What you have to do is to secure your civilization a place in history. But why I give 4.0? It won't help you get started at all. I'm not asking for a strategy guide, I just wanna learn the basics of the game, what's unique to it, what options I have and what they do. I couldn't find a tutorial or at least a checkbox to display tooltips, even the options in the main menu don't have a basic description. It's one of the less intuitive game I've ever seen, unlike it's predecessor ou sucessor. Of course after sometime you'll start to get used to the controls, but they still feel weird. The UI is not friendly even for games older than it is, Age of Empires II is older and has a much more friendly interface and controls.Graphics - 2.5The game looks very bad even for its generation, Age of Wonders and Medieval Total War had much better visual quality. Civilization III looks so bad that if affects gameplay, you need to often take a closer look to identify some terrains and unities. There are no options for good graphic enhancements, you can not adjust resolution, it's based on desktop resolution, and even tweaking can't get satisfactory results. I know it's an old game, but the ones I cited are old too and are from the same genre. At least the game showed an improvement compared to the previous title, texture quality is better and there are movement animations for the unities.Overall - 5.8Current specsIntel Core I7-4770K at 4.2ghzNvidia PNY GTX 770 2gb at 1201mhzKingston HyperX DDR3 8gb at 1600mhz (x2)HP 1TB SATA III 7200rpmWindows 7 Premium SP1Sony Bravia KDL-42W655A at 1080p

number of helpful: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												I purchased this game in order to understand and have an enlightenment on the essential game mechanics of the Civilization game series. I am still not sure whether Civilization III was the right choice.Here are a few topics that I wish to highlight:- It is a low-paced, turn-based strategy game with a significant amount of historical content.- There are a few variables in the game that the person should learn before starting to play. Luckily, steam provides us with a manual, so DO read it.- For beginners, this game may become tough, even at the lowest difficulty setting. Even after learning the basics, there are many things one can do wrong.- This game can take MANY hours of your time, and once your civilization has more than 10 settlements, it may take more than a minute to play each game turn. In addition, there may be dozens and dozens of turns before a victory condition is met.- Although it DOES seem to work on my Windows 8.1 machine, there are a few frustrating issues, such as window switching not restoring the original resolution until the game is terminated. Also, the game may occasionally crash on some particular user, and so far it has always crashed after the end of a game. This means that the game could have had a better preparation for modern systems.Therefore, it is both hard to recommend and unrecommend this game. Take this as a midline evaluation. If you have time to spare, go ahead and give it a try. Or who knows, the other games in the series might be more interesting.

Product received for free
												I'm sorry, but the game is way too buggy, and super slow when playing with others. I was in a multiplayer game with one other person, and we only got to 640 AD after playing for 3 hours straight. Also, as I retired in anger, the game crashed as I tried to close it. Also, unit stacking is possibly the worst feature the Civ series has ever had. You order your units to move, and they move one... by one... by one... until you are in your coffin, 600 years later, and you finally get that last spearman over. Speaking of units, these cities keep on making military units, past your limit, and you are soon in civil disorder because of money. Money should never be a problem in a Civ game, ever! I'd hate to give this game a bad review, as Civilization is one of my favorite game series(es?) of all time. Please, save your five dollars and use it on something else. May I suggest: save 25 more of those dollars for Civ 5? Or, you know, any other game?

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Let me say that this was my first Civilization game, and for being on sale for $5, I am sure I would buy the game again.If you're new or interested in Civilization games, I HIGHLY recommend reading further and/or watching videos to understand what you are getting into:Pros-This game is highly detailed and allows for a significant amount of strategy-management decisions. Learning the system and "how to beat it" itself was an enjoyable that I still can't fully claim to have achieved.Cons-There is no help in-game in actually learning the game. This will either add hours of patience in learning the game, or frustration.The computer AI is abhorrent for trading.Fair Warning: This game is SLOW. I am okay about slow games, when I am mentally prepared for it. This game is so slow, whether due to micromanagement, organizing your thoughts, or constant unit/city decisions. In my opinion, the pacing of this game is not evidence of a detailed well thought out game (which yes, it is), but of a poorly designed game. Even in "speed-mode"...just ugh, it's still slow.I suggest that if you are interested in a strategic, decision-making game, and ok with long games, the Civilization games will suit your needs. Furthermore, I suggest looking into Galactic Civilizations, at the least for the sake of a real tutorial.Again, if you're new to these games, do your research and check out other people's opinions before diving into the Civilization world.

number of helpful: 2 of 26 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												Well I was hoping for a different experience from Civ IV.  I was hoping that Civ IV was that point where the devs went through a 'lets temporarily sell out and ♥♥♥♥ up the franchise for a while' phase, but it turns out Civ III is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as well.Okay, it's not as silly as Civ IV.  In may ways, I still despise Civ IV, but I'll admit it's a nitpick.  I'd give it the same rating otherwise, because it's almost the same game.  Civ IV's interpretation of religion is silly.  Read the other review for more about that.Okay, enough about ♥♥♥♥ing Civ IV, lets talk about Civ III.  But what is there to talk about really?  I tried to have fun, but it was the dullest 5 hours on chieftain (easiest difficulty) of moving around a bunch of soldiers and workers (that's all this game is, soldiers and workers and building ROADS) with the scandinavian vikings that I used to conquer the Aztec empire (ultimately a game of city tag), while fending off Japanese and Romans, I've ever had.  Eventually, I resigned, because Sumeria was really big, Persia entered a 'golden age', and I had to end it at some point.There was no way to end this game properly without playing for another 8 hours, and that was a standard size map.  The one thing I sorta appreciated was how the enemy leaders poke fun at you for quitting.  The victory screen scores, such as 'children per family', 'population', and 'average lifespan', are mostly purely for flair and meaningless.  Final Score - 38/100

												This is my favorite of the Civilization franchise because of its pace. Unlike IV and V it is easy to raise large armies and lots of cities. 												I have been playing Civ 3 since I was... hm... actually I'm not entirely sure. It's been a really long time. When it went on sale on the Humble Bundle, I had to get it. The game is simple enough that I could play and enjoy it on the lowest difficulty as a little kid, but complex enough that if you don't think about what you're doing on a higher difficulty setting, you will screw up.I'm currently taking a World Politics class at my college, and I'm constantly realizing just how spot on with how the world operates that the Civilization series as a whole is. Dealing with your citizens while at the same time maintaining foreign relations. Making sure you don't owe the other civs too much. Deciding how much funding you want in each and every little thing...*Sigh* It's a good time.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												If you love the wargame aspect of the CIVILIZATION games, this game still has a lot to offer.  I put in a lot of hours in the last two weeks.  Domination games ran about 48 hrs on the lowest setting, longer at higher settings where one must think more about each move, for those who like to micromanage....keep cranking up the difficulty level.   Sorry, CIV I and II fans.  No more Diplomat units.  A very different experience than CIV IV, which became awesome with all the fine mods available.  I admit. This game hits my Turn-Based-Strategy  sweet spot for kicking back and wargaming.  One of the best "old" computer games I bought in the last year, not because I did not have it already; because for $5 I got to play an apparently bug  free game inside of 5 minutes on Windows 7 and no making it run on a VM virtual machine.  Gets my Happy Camper award.MAJOR IRRITATING PROBLEM:  From the origional, after a unit moves, the game jumps to the next (not nearest) unit that may be half a world away.  There is no way to stop and look at what your just-moved unit saw without scrolling to find it.  This becomes very irritating after a while.  I had forgotten about it.  It is not a bug, it is programming design.  This got fixed in later games so the game paused after each unit moves, allowing you to stay in an area and complete a battle before moving on by hitting a key when YOU are ready.  Think of a scar on Mona Lisa's face.   Think of a good movie that periodically stutters, jumps or freezes.   Oh, wait.  I already have that.  Verison FIOS, may the gods bless their awesome up and download speeds.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												Civ 3 has kinda been forgotten now with Civ 4 and Civ 5 out, but it remains my favourite. Whilst I can't think of anything in particualar that it did better (other than the attack/defense of troops instead of some weird strength system that makes no sense and a clear hit point bar showing you how much health your troops have left) the overall feel of this game (and it's soundtrack!) make for the most fun out of the 3 games (3, 4 and 5) that I have played. Civ 3 was the first game of the series I played and so there may be a lot of bias based on nostalgic value here, but I still highly reccomend this game to any strategy fan.

												My favorite Civilization game, despite its flaws and quirks. I spent a good 10+ years playing this particular entry, and even own multiple copies of it in various forms. (3 to be exact!) I'm a real power gamer when it comes to turn based strategy, and I've always found everything in Civ III to be very easy to minmax. Maybe that comes from over ten years of experience with the game. But I just can't truly get bored of this. Even if I do own Civ IV and V I still find myself going back to III on occasion. I want to chalk it up to it being a good game and not just my own nostalgia.For $5 (and under during sales) this is a really good deal and you can't really go wrong with Civilization, now can you?

Posted: December 17, 2014
												My first real video game, being brought up on all those educational "Leap Start" games from way back when, never getting any real games until this one, I loved it from the very first turn. This game is quite possibly one of the best strategy games ever created. It has perfect balance, great gameplay, its very hard to win but you still have fun with it because of the flawless design, the units are all unique and each one is cool in its own way, from the days of stones and swords to fighter jets and skyscrapers, you'll have fun forever. I still remember my first victory, so many years later. I remember just how proud I was, looking at all those beat up other leaders, mine staring at them with a♥♥♥♥♥♥faced grin of complete pompus superiority, I felt like I was god. When you actually win, which I've only done once, it feels SO ♥♥♥♥ING GOOD. You feel like you just took over the world in real life, especially with all the other leaders sitting there, cowering before your might! Its just awesome, please please buy this game, it is a classic that will never die, and everyone should get it, try it at least once. 9001/10

												A poor job was done of updating this classic for Steam.  The game works, but a lot of the in game text messages are screwed up. Posted: June 27, 2015
												Probably my favourite of the Civilization series! An oldie but a goodie. It's simpler than Civ IV, and still has loads to do. Plus it's based on the old square tile system instead of the hexagonal system, which is great for if you're not used to turn-based strategy gameplay. Finally, this game has absolutely wonderful music that doesn't get old. Especially when you hit the modern era and end up watching 100+ bombers blow the countryside to smithereens.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												The franchise is run through to the bitter end, with players opting for piracy and spacecraft without help or hail-mary, as the plot devolves unerringly to next advances in technology. The tech tree from Civilization II carried the throne room. In Civ III, the multiplayer and marginalised are in an open door to cultural centres around the world, egging on the tech-savvy, New York hipster, python coding sky rise. The introduction is the selling point. Closing on the propogandist last installment, Civilization V: Brave New World. Not everyone knows, but Huxley's Brave New World Revisited is a non-fiction debacle couched in a comfortable sequel for bugs from early adolescence to young adulthood. The gateway to television since Iraq is clouded by war still now, and today, a friendly reminder of our spiritual needs as anthropogists is as healthy as any Black Sabbath. Drugs tear families apart. But babies need drugs to grow. Weather control is a superpower. I recommend frequent save games with a friend

Posted: May 26, 2015
												Are you looking for a Time sink?Here you are!This is a basic turned based Real Time Strategy game based around building a civilation from a tribal state to a modern age.The Charm of this game really comes from your opponates, how they'll mock you, or try to threaten you to give them what they want. You can completely civil, or you can be a thorn in everyone's side, which can get to the point of the entire planet trying to destroy you.A problem is that the mechanics can be confusing, heck it took me a solid three hours of reading to get a basic grasp on the game. but once you learn it, it's down, and it become second nature.Another problem, if you can call it one, is that this game will burn hours of your life without your consent, seriously, you will play 4 hours stright and swear it was maybe 30 minutes.8/10 PROS:Great RTS game playAged nicelygreat freedom to chooseCONS:Quite a few things to learn to even start playingWill sink hours without you knowing it.

												Review written ~20 hours playtimes;This game is fun, that said it is fun for a certain type of people, I tend to enjoy the early game most(I have trouble actually keeping large militaries)First off you have to micromanage to be effective for longer than a few dozens of turns. You have to at least a thousand years in the future to avoid dead ends. You will at some point have to deal with long stretches of nothing to do but click the next turn button. Which WILL leave you paranoid that your enemy is pulling ahead. (On higher difficulties they are)That said seeing a strategy work when you weren't certain it would, or looking at the 5-6 techs you have on EVERYONE can be amazing.So if you like a game that makes you fear idling, an AI that won't give you a break, and some amazing victories, pick it up.If you have the dosh though pick up one the later ones first;

Posted: May 24, 2015
												The franchise is run through to the bitter end, with players opting for piracy and spacecraft without help or hail-mary, as the plot devolves unerringly to next advances in technology. The tech tree from Civilization II carried the throne room. In Civ III, the multiplayer and marginalised are in an open door to cultural centres around the world, egging on the tech-savvy, New York hipster, python coding sky rise. The introduction is the selling point. Closing on the propogandist last installment, Civilization V: Brave New World. Not everyone knows, but Huxley's Brave New World Revisited is a non-fiction debacle couched in a comfortable sequel for bugs from early adolescence to young adulthood. The gateway to television since Iraq is clouded by war still now, and today, a friendly reminder of our spiritual needs as anthropogists is as healthy as any Black Sabbath. Drugs tear families apart. But babies need drugs to grow. Weather control is a superpower. I recommend frequent save games with a friend

Posted: May 26, 2015
												Are you looking for a Time sink?Here you are!This is a basic turned based Real Time Strategy game based around building a civilation from a tribal state to a modern age.The Charm of this game really comes from your opponates, how they'll mock you, or try to threaten you to give them what they want. You can completely civil, or you can be a thorn in everyone's side, which can get to the point of the entire planet trying to destroy you.A problem is that the mechanics can be confusing, heck it took me a solid three hours of reading to get a basic grasp on the game. but once you learn it, it's down, and it become second nature.Another problem, if you can call it one, is that this game will burn hours of your life without your consent, seriously, you will play 4 hours stright and swear it was maybe 30 minutes.8/10 PROS:Great RTS game playAged nicelygreat freedom to chooseCONS:Quite a few things to learn to even start playingWill sink hours without you knowing it.

Posted: December 17, 2014
												My first real video game, being brought up on all those educational "Leap Start" games from way back when, never getting any real games until this one, I loved it from the very first turn. This game is quite possibly one of the best strategy games ever created. It has perfect balance, great gameplay, its very hard to win but you still have fun with it because of the flawless design, the units are all unique and each one is cool in its own way, from the days of stones and swords to fighter jets and skyscrapers, you'll have fun forever. I still remember my first victory, so many years later. I remember just how proud I was, looking at all those beat up other leaders, mine staring at them with a♥♥♥♥♥♥faced grin of complete pompus superiority, I felt like I was god. When you actually win, which I've only done once, it feels SO ♥♥♥♥ING GOOD. You feel like you just took over the world in real life, especially with all the other leaders sitting there, cowering before your might! Its just awesome, please please buy this game, it is a classic that will never die, and everyone should get it, try it at least once. 9001/10

Posted: June 21, 2014
												OKay, First off, this may be a little biased as Civ 3 was the game that introduced me to the franchise. That said, It' s a solid 4X title, Graphically, it's obviously not going to be State of the Art, but I've never found that to matter with this genre; and apparently neither have most people given that one of the most popular 4X games around is Alpha Centari, which came out in 1999. Sorry, got a bit off topic.Like all the Civ games, Civilization 3 puts you in control of a settler and warrior, kicks you into the oceon that is its game play and tells you to swim. The tutorial is there, but it's basically a series of tips that pop up when you start doing things. well written and concise, but they don't force your hand. Also like the other Civ games, there is a large tech tree and ages to advance through as your empire grows. The main appeal of the game is that no two playthroughs [which can take weeks to months if you play casually] are ever going to be the same. One game History may play out as you destroy the Aztecs as the Spanish... but in the next game, Gahndi might nuke your American♥♥♥♥♥into oblivion. Ultimately, 4X games aren't for everyone, but everyone should give the genre a try and at the price they're asking for it, Civ 3 is an affordable, still good looking, and complete introduction to the genre as well as a game that experienced players will enjoy for years to come.[[A note on the CIv Franchise: those of you who started civ with 4 or 5 should also give 3 a try, the three titles are honestly different enough that they could be said to be equally good in their own right, assuming of course that you have the DLC for Civ 5, otherwise.... *shudders*]]

												Civilization is the best strategy (none space) 4x game ever made, I love all the Civ games, and Civ3 Call to Power is my favorite, unfortunately it's not avalible on Steam. but none of the Civ games are bad, and this one is also really good, even it's quite old now and the graphics might suck a bit, but these kind of games are not played because of graphics, they are played because of strategy and tactics, then the graphics  doesn't really matter. because it's all about the game play. Posted: October 7, 2015
												--My review is done from the viewpoint of having played the iOS version of Civilization: Revolution--Thanks to playing Revolution, I had some idea of how everything would work.  I do recommend finding tutorials on this if you've never played anything Civ before.  http://cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/3910/manuals/manual.pdf?t=1400366001  This seems to be a very complete version of the manual, maybe to such a degree as to be an overload of information, but it should be useful in addressing issues.My first impression is that it is a good game, with a decent balance between depth and simplicity in the gameplay.  It is not so overwhelming as to completely kill any hopes of learning how it works, but it is no walk in the park either.  If you prefer simplicity though, you're better off playing Revolution.I enjoyed the half-hour that I spent playing it, and I'll hopefully get some more time in every now and again.  When I do, I'll try and update this review with more details.So to sum it up, it's a good game, fair level of complexity, if you prefer simplicity, play Revolution instead.

Posted: November 14, 2016
												Sid Meier’s Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn’t completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn’t do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn’t look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it’s complicated mechanics. One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don’t expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

Posted: May 16, 2016
												I have civ5 complete too. Like some of the other reviews I found the game fairly different from civ5. Definitely worth the buy ($1.37 on sale). Not having the culture group stuff from civ 5 makes the game alot better. Another up compared to civ 5 is that it doesnt have the fancy graphics, so I can run it on my work laptop (which has no dedicated gpu) [civ 5 to go? lel].I find the whole idea of *clicking on my temple to add an upgrade (all visual?)* pretty pointless and dumb. I literally just hover my touchpad over the whole screen till i hear a sound, then click and escape. It was pretty annoying to The time it takes to finish a game is both a pro and con. If you are a time sensitive person I would suggest you turn off move animations for all units because you will leterally have your eye pop out waiting for allt he units to move at the end. Some of the other default settings also made the game annoying to play. In particular, if you have units which are fortified or in alert stances, the turn may very well pass away under the default setting unless you do some annoying repetitive camerfa movement. There was a setting to wait at the end of ever turn to make this easier, I'm totally fine hitting space bar or enter at the end of every turn then watch things happen in a way i didn't want it.I still have to learn about some other mechanisms in this game before I comment further. I'll probably add more next time i stop by.

Posted: February 3, 2016
												Date: 2/2/16Review Number: 7Game: Sid Meier’s Civilization IIIFrom (Creator Publisher): Firaxis / 2k gamesPlayed On: LaptopSteam Price as of Review: $4.99Total Time played: 60 minutesReview:I had been waiting for this game, and really I was surprised that it came up so quickly in the randomizer.  Now, I have been a fan of the civilization series for well over a decade and a half, since the first version came out on PC, and have played it in one form or another almost constantly between then and now, and on nearly every console or PC I have owned.  That being said, more often than not the versions I have played have either been first generation games or one of the many free clones, so it was a treat to be able to play one of  the games I haven’t played yet.Now, I have to admit that spending only an hour on any civilization game isn’t quite enough to have an adequate run with the game, but I still intend to give it a review based on that limited experience.  The gameplay is solid, though Civilization has a steep learning curve, providing little in terms of understanding asset management and growth.  This version does allow workers to auto-update the surrounding areas around the cities, so some of the more mundane tasks of the earlier versions are removed ,at least to an extent, however the controls around individual units have been reduced to a sort of drag and drop system, which can get confusing, especially when requiring units to change direction mid order.  The graphics are about what you can expect from a fifteen year old civilization game, though units are easily enough distinguished from each other, there isn't much else there in terms of fancy looks.  But then again, that isn’t why you’re playing.  Instead, you’re playing to feel the inexorable crushing defeat of having your little peaceful civilization on the  corner of the map overrun by whoever is the aggressive one of the AI monsters.  You play to waste time clicking on your cities each turn to watch the build counters drop.  You play to try, and fail, to understand why your citizens in just that one city won’t shut the ♥♥♥♥ up about taxes.  I mean, come on, every other city is okay with it.  You really don’t have much to complain about.  So why riot?  I certainly wouldn’t know.Game’s Fate: This one will remain, and probably take up all my spare game playing time, at least until another one of the series comes up in the randomizer to replace it.Buy/No Buy: Does Ghandi love Nukes?  you damn right you should buy this

Posted: October 7, 2015
												--My review is done from the viewpoint of having played the iOS version of Civilization: Revolution--Thanks to playing Revolution, I had some idea of how everything would work.  I do recommend finding tutorials on this if you've never played anything Civ before.  http://cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/3910/manuals/manual.pdf?t=1400366001  This seems to be a very complete version of the manual, maybe to such a degree as to be an overload of information, but it should be useful in addressing issues.My first impression is that it is a good game, with a decent balance between depth and simplicity in the gameplay.  It is not so overwhelming as to completely kill any hopes of learning how it works, but it is no walk in the park either.  If you prefer simplicity though, you're better off playing Revolution.I enjoyed the half-hour that I spent playing it, and I'll hopefully get some more time in every now and again.  When I do, I'll try and update this review with more details.So to sum it up, it's a good game, fair level of complexity, if you prefer simplicity, play Revolution instead.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												Bought this originally when PC games came out in those big square boxes, and to be fair it does show its age. The graphics aren't enivable at all because, well, it is nearly 14 years old. It crashes sometimes too. There is quite a learning curve, but after a while you do get through it. The AI is random or too predictable at times, if they plop a stack randomly into your territory and refuse to leave, they're 90% going to declare war. Playing on easier levels, outsmarting the AI is fairly formulaic, aggressive expansion for the first half, strategically stealing all resources and then ploughing through them all. Small maps are too small, and if you create a massive map (which you can do in the editor, which itself has a learning curve) there is a city limit of 450. The game reaches its limit, but by that point each turn is so long, why bother. Naval conflict is always a bit piddly too. But really the base game has a simple enough format that its almost like a PC version of Monopoly. You can play it again and again, no fancy 3D experience or anything, the graphics really don't impede gameplay. 14 years later its still perfectly playable and, importantly, provides a fun and varied experience. Each game comes out wildly different from the last one, and every time you play a new challenge will arise. The randomized earths created offer nearly infinite variety and eliminate any boredom you could experience with similar games. I can easily play this game for hours and hours. Similar to Paradox games, once you start a campaign its hard to finish, there is enough variety in maps you always want to do something else. Games can easily go far into the future, and with some mods you can add some variety onto the existing game's timeline. 9/10 game!

Posted: March 6, 2014
												A little less than a decade ago, this game got me started on the whole Civilization series. It was definitely a life-changer: after many years of playing, I liked it so much that when Civ 4 came out I still preferred 3 over the new one. The map editor included with the game is very straightforward to use - that's always a plus with any game. (cf. StarCraft) I used to use it to do things like editing the Earth map so that all the civs start at their actual capital locations. Oh what fun I had over the years, not only standing the test of time but also writing my own world history...Now that I am well and truly a Civ 5 player, I doubt I'll ever go back to this game; but this game is definitely worth a play if you have never played any of the Civilization games before. While I do recommend that you start with the latest title, it could also be a good idea to start at 3 and work your way up, see how things have changed over the past decade.... Just don't come blaming me 5 hours later asking where all your time has gone after just a few "short" turns.

Posted: November 13, 2016
												If you're looking for ludicrous and war-mongering AI, as well as the ability to make your civilization happy without a circus and other buildings that provide happiness, this is the game for you!In all seriousness, this is a great game. It is 100% worth the $1.24 you pay when it goes on sale! It is very easy to manage your cities' happiness and production! With Civ III, you can que production items, unlike Civ V, which makes the game enjoyable. As well as allows you to have very productive cities. The way it makes that aspect of the game more enjoyable is that you don't have to click on the choose production icon every few turns. However, it sometimes likes to just switch to needless outdated military units after it runs out of production items in a que. Another nice feature of this game is the selecting how you want your game to be set up. It allows you to choose how old the earth is when you start the game. As well as has a few more features that are absent in Civ 5.The only cons to this are the aforementioned AI, and playing it on a newer computer. The AI are typically kind of crazy when it comes to deals, and get really annoyed if you decline them. Which typically leads to war with them eventually. I seem to have a problem where the AI all declare war with me. Also, the AI expand their civilizations really fast, so if you buy this, make sure to settle as many cities as possible in the beginning of the game! Although that really applies to any Civ Game. Finally, Civ 3 seems to run too fast on newer computers, and it will skip through some animations. Other than that, this is a really great game! Especially when it is slightly more expensive than a pack of gum!

Posted: November 14, 2016
												Sid Meier’s Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn’t completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn’t do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn’t look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it’s complicated mechanics. One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don’t expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

Posted: December 4, 2016
												Civilization has been one of the main cornerstones of the 4X genre since its first entry in the 90s. I grew up playing tons of Civilization II until my brother got a copy of Civilization III for Christmas, and I've loved it ever since.PROS:+Grand strategy based on ruling an empire and balancing multiple facets including your militaristic, economic, industrial, scientific, and diplomatic agendas.+Impressive number of Civilizations to play as (over 30), each with its own advantages and disadvantages.+Despite the number of potential Civilizations, each plays with its own distinctive style.+More peaceful options to win than spaceship-building.+Numerous scenarios (or Conquests) including WWII in the Pacific, Sengoku-era Japan, Pre- and Post-Columbus America, and the Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire.+Abnormally good soundtrack.+Difficult to master, like many good strategy games.+Introduces new game mechanics like war weariness, forced labor, and corruption.+Included is a Scenario-maker, which is very comprehensive and allows for the addition of entirely-new civilizations, technologies, and maps.+There's many of the popular fan-made maps and scenarios already installed with the game.+Mods! (on CivFanatics)CONS:-Loses some of the characteristics form Civilization II (such as wonder movies, animated high councils, and "Our words are backed with NUCLEAR WEAPONS!"-Doesn't run as well on modern machines. I've had game crashes on the Victory Screen, but I've heard of people not even being able to start the game.-Tutorial hints hidden in the Preferences menu, so unless you've played Civilization II or IV, this one's pretty hard to learn. Other Civilizations (including this game's direct predacessor) automatically turned on the hints if played on the lowest difficulty, or had menus for learning the game.Personally, it's my favorite of the grid-based Civilizations, and I always come back for more.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												This game is complicated, difficult, frustrating, and oh my goodness so much fun. I think this is probably *the* gold standard for turn-based strategy games, even now, all these years later. I've tried later iterations of the Civ franchise, but /// is still my favourite. The 2D graphics are clear and very pretty. The mechanics are incredibly detailed and complicated, but also fit nicely together into a unified whole. The gameplay is fun, and the game always gives you plenty of different things to do -- without making you feel overwhelmed (well, at least once you get used to the basics). The interface gives you access to tons of information and lots and lots of options without ever feeling cluttered; in fact, on most of the screens you'll be seeing, the UI feels slick and very attractive, while still remaining effective. The game even has a lovely sense of humour -- the "you say you want a revolution?" bit always makes me smile. :)In short, this is one of the very best computer games I've ever played, in any genre, and definitely the best strategy game. At this ridiculously low price, which includes all of the game's various expansions (including internet multiplayer, which still works very nicely and will lead to lots of fun and/or horribly frustrating gameplay time with friends), there is no reason not to snap it up.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												From the very beginning, every mainline edition of the Civilization series has gotten an average of a 90-95% user approval rate which is a greater approval rate than that normally ascribed to civilization itself. This could be due to the fact that the Civilization seies simply soars while civilization itself seems to soar and stink in equal measure. Then again, it could be that the game of Civilization simply appeals to the inner narcissist lurking somewhere within us all. After all, how often is it you can be elected ruler of your nation by popular acclaim, rule them in a governmental form of your choice, eventually rise to rule to world, establish Earth's first off world colony, and live for centuries. I have to admit that is slightly more ambitious than my own real world expectations, but I do have an eye on the North American continent. Consider yourself warned.Now don't get me wrong here. I am not trying to say that Civilization is the best turn based, civ building, strategy game ever. That would be unfair to all those games I have not gotten around to trying. What I can say is that it is by far the best I have ever played, and narcissist that I am, I will try most anything that gives me a shot at world domination.The Civilization series is up to Civ-5 at this point, but Civ-3 is a game which endures the times, remains comparable to like games of more recent production, and holds a special place in my heart when compared to the newer versions of this long running classic. Later editions of this game introduce elements which alter the play style and base strategy of the game, but while I believe that Civ-4 & 5 remain true to the original construct to a large degree, it is Civ-3 which most closely  resembles the original. In fact, it is exactly like the original, but with greater user options, and smoother game play. If you have been thinking about giving this series a try, Civ-3 is a great place to start. With the release of Civ-5, the Steam price for Civ-3 is a mere $5.00 which in my opinion makes it one of the best bargains in the entire Steam Library. Just one run through of this game will keep you occupied for longer than the run time of a long movie, and when was the last time you got into a movie theatre for &5.00 eh? I began playing this game when it first came out for PC in the 90's, continue to play it to this day, and played Civ-1 & 2 before that. How's that for a testament for long term replayability? I simply could not recommend another game of this type more highly.

Posted: November 13, 2016
												If you're looking for ludicrous and war-mongering AI, as well as the ability to make your civilization happy without a circus and other buildings that provide happiness, this is the game for you!In all seriousness, this is a great game. It is 100% worth the $1.24 you pay when it goes on sale! It is very easy to manage your cities' happiness and production! With Civ III, you can que production items, unlike Civ V, which makes the game enjoyable. As well as allows you to have very productive cities. The way it makes that aspect of the game more enjoyable is that you don't have to click on the choose production icon every few turns. However, it sometimes likes to just switch to needless outdated military units after it runs out of production items in a que. Another nice feature of this game is the selecting how you want your game to be set up. It allows you to choose how old the earth is when you start the game. As well as has a few more features that are absent in Civ 5.The only cons to this are the aforementioned AI, and playing it on a newer computer. The AI are typically kind of crazy when it comes to deals, and get really annoyed if you decline them. Which typically leads to war with them eventually. I seem to have a problem where the AI all declare war with me. Also, the AI expand their civilizations really fast, so if you buy this, make sure to settle as many cities as possible in the beginning of the game! Although that really applies to any Civ Game. Finally, Civ 3 seems to run too fast on newer computers, and it will skip through some animations. Other than that, this is a really great game! Especially when it is slightly more expensive than a pack of gum!

Posted: November 14, 2016
												Sid Meier’s Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn’t completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn’t do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn’t look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it’s complicated mechanics. One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don’t expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

Posted: February 3, 2016
												Date: 2/2/16Review Number: 7Game: Sid Meier’s Civilization IIIFrom (Creator Publisher): Firaxis / 2k gamesPlayed On: LaptopSteam Price as of Review: $4.99Total Time played: 60 minutesReview:I had been waiting for this game, and really I was surprised that it came up so quickly in the randomizer.  Now, I have been a fan of the civilization series for well over a decade and a half, since the first version came out on PC, and have played it in one form or another almost constantly between then and now, and on nearly every console or PC I have owned.  That being said, more often than not the versions I have played have either been first generation games or one of the many free clones, so it was a treat to be able to play one of  the games I haven’t played yet.Now, I have to admit that spending only an hour on any civilization game isn’t quite enough to have an adequate run with the game, but I still intend to give it a review based on that limited experience.  The gameplay is solid, though Civilization has a steep learning curve, providing little in terms of understanding asset management and growth.  This version does allow workers to auto-update the surrounding areas around the cities, so some of the more mundane tasks of the earlier versions are removed ,at least to an extent, however the controls around individual units have been reduced to a sort of drag and drop system, which can get confusing, especially when requiring units to change direction mid order.  The graphics are about what you can expect from a fifteen year old civilization game, though units are easily enough distinguished from each other, there isn't much else there in terms of fancy looks.  But then again, that isn’t why you’re playing.  Instead, you’re playing to feel the inexorable crushing defeat of having your little peaceful civilization on the  corner of the map overrun by whoever is the aggressive one of the AI monsters.  You play to waste time clicking on your cities each turn to watch the build counters drop.  You play to try, and fail, to understand why your citizens in just that one city won’t shut the ♥♥♥♥ up about taxes.  I mean, come on, every other city is okay with it.  You really don’t have much to complain about.  So why riot?  I certainly wouldn’t know.Game’s Fate: This one will remain, and probably take up all my spare game playing time, at least until another one of the series comes up in the randomizer to replace it.Buy/No Buy: Does Ghandi love Nukes?  you damn right you should buy this

Posted: November 28, 2016
												My hours played do not reflect my time on this game, because I had it long, long before it was out on Steam.  What game could better deserve the 'Test of Time' award (except, perhaps, Civ 2: Test of Time, but that's not on Steam).  Civ 3 has a timeless appeal that will bring old players back, and give new players (who, perhaps, have played a more recent Civ) a look at the glorious history of the series.  The beginnings of National Wonders, the Worker/Settler split, rivers on tile borders, rather than on tiles.  All these and more began with Civ 3.

Posted: December 4, 2016
												Civilization has been one of the main cornerstones of the 4X genre since its first entry in the 90s. I grew up playing tons of Civilization II until my brother got a copy of Civilization III for Christmas, and I've loved it ever since.PROS:+Grand strategy based on ruling an empire and balancing multiple facets including your militaristic, economic, industrial, scientific, and diplomatic agendas.+Impressive number of Civilizations to play as (over 30), each with its own advantages and disadvantages.+Despite the number of potential Civilizations, each plays with its own distinctive style.+More peaceful options to win than spaceship-building.+Numerous scenarios (or Conquests) including WWII in the Pacific, Sengoku-era Japan, Pre- and Post-Columbus America, and the Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire.+Abnormally good soundtrack.+Difficult to master, like many good strategy games.+Introduces new game mechanics like war weariness, forced labor, and corruption.+Included is a Scenario-maker, which is very comprehensive and allows for the addition of entirely-new civilizations, technologies, and maps.+There's many of the popular fan-made maps and scenarios already installed with the game.+Mods! (on CivFanatics)CONS:-Loses some of the characteristics form Civilization II (such as wonder movies, animated high councils, and "Our words are backed with NUCLEAR WEAPONS!"-Doesn't run as well on modern machines. I've had game crashes on the Victory Screen, but I've heard of people not even being able to start the game.-Tutorial hints hidden in the Preferences menu, so unless you've played Civilization II or IV, this one's pretty hard to learn. Other Civilizations (including this game's direct predacessor) automatically turned on the hints if played on the lowest difficulty, or had menus for learning the game.Personally, it's my favorite of the grid-based Civilizations, and I always come back for more.

Posted: December 5, 2016
												So first off I'm going to start by saying even though it might show about an hour or so of playtime it does not mean I have not played this game before. I first came across this game at GameStop and I really hadn't played any games since I was young. But I needed a past time because I was dying of boredom being at home laid up in bed unable to do much. I had severely injured my back and I wasn't going to work anytime soon and the depression started to kick in. So anyways by now the game had been out for about 3 years and it looked interesting so I bought it. Went home and started playing it and it was my first time playing a strategy game so I didn't even know if I was going to like it. I started playing around lunch time by the time I know it was dinner time so took 10 minutes got my food and came back and ate while I played. By the time I knew it was freaking 6am the next day! I had never had lost track of time by that much, but man was I enjoying the game. I thought the graphics were pretty decent, the game play was very good and the UI was also good. Of course it was the first time I've had played a game with an in game Civilopedia and I thought that was awesome. The other thing I miss from Civilization III that has not been added to any other Civilization since is building your capital building when your citizens were happy you were able to add one section at a time until you finished upgrading your building. I thought that was fun, even though it was a very simple and quick thing. By the time Civilization IV came out I had around 3500 hours invested in this game and I still have the original disk I bought, but I went ahead and bought it on Steam because they had a very good deal on Civ III, IV and Colonization which I already have the other two also. But I want to keep those disks from getting any damage and besides Steam keeps a running track of your gaming time. So I can safely say this game is what got me back into gaming and becoming a full time gamer. I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME, EVEN THOUGH IT'S AN OLDER GAME. Keep gaming.

												A very confusing game to play if it is your first time playing a Civ or other turn based strategy game. With enough perseverance, you'll learn the ropes though. While a more simple game than its successors Civ 4 and Civ 5, this game is extremely complex but still wildly fun and addicting. It doesn't make my computer slow at all and is fun to play alone, especially in an airport or on a sick day. It can, however, still be enjoyed just as much in 5 minute intervals as a pick-up-and-play game. 5/5 would recommend to anyone with patience and an appreciation for historical accuracy.

I had never had lost track of time by that much, but man was I enjoying the game. I thought the graphics were pretty decent, the game play was very good and the UI was also good. Of course it was the first time I've had played a game with an in game Civilopedia and I thought that was awesome. The other thing I miss from Civilization III that has not been added to any other Civilization since is building your capital building when your citizens were happy you were able to add one section at a time until you finished upgrading your building. I thought that was fun, even though it was a very simple and quick thing. By the time Civilization IV came out I had around 3500 hours invested in this game and I still have the original disk I bought, but I went ahead and bought it on Steam because they had a very good deal on Civ III, IV and Colonization which I already have the other two also. But I want to keep those disks from getting any damage and besides Steam keeps a running track of your gaming time. So I can safely say this game is what got me back into gaming and becoming a full time gamer. I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME, EVEN THOUGH IT'S AN OLDER GAME. Keep gaming.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												This game is complicated, difficult, frustrating, and oh my goodness so much fun. I think this is probably *the* gold standard for turn-based strategy games, even now, all these years later. I've tried later iterations of the Civ franchise, but /// is still my favourite. The 2D graphics are clear and very pretty. The mechanics are incredibly detailed and complicated, but also fit nicely together into a unified whole. The gameplay is fun, and the game always gives you plenty of different things to do -- without making you feel overwhelmed (well, at least once you get used to the basics). The interface gives you access to tons of information and lots and lots of options without ever feeling cluttered; in fact, on most of the screens you'll be seeing, the UI feels slick and very attractive, while still remaining effective. The game even has a lovely sense of humour -- the "you say you want a revolution?" bit always makes me smile. :)In short, this is one of the very best computer games I've ever played, in any genre, and definitely the best strategy game. At this ridiculously low price, which includes all of the game's various expansions (including internet multiplayer, which still works very nicely and will lead to lots of fun and/or horribly frustrating gameplay time with friends), there is no reason not to snap it up.

Posted: March 1
												For those who wish civ 5 and 6 are too complex and overly detailed, and want to play a simplier, more caual civ builder, then id recommend civ 3. You're able to epand and control your empire with ease. You baely need worry about whether you have enough resources to build certain units, as long as you have whats needed to make them (i.e.-swordsman need iron). Buildings and improvements finish production quickly, units are easy to move and can be watched as the avartars fight on your map in front of you. Its not for hardcore civi gamers who want challenge and complexty, its for casuals who just want to vent some stress by invading and massacaring a neighboring civilization.features include-diplomacy, combat, instructing workers and armies, building roads and railways, choosing what sciences to discover, trade, world wonders, differing ideologies and several ways of winning the game.

Posted: April 22
												I bought Civ III from the grocery store. It was in some 10 dollar PC game dump, and I saw the holy grail standing out. I picked it out and never saw anything like it. Had to beg my mom for it. That was 2004. Played it for years off and on, trying to learn everything about Civ III will drive you mad. Little did I know there was a complete edition with so much more content. Civ III Complete is the best Civ game. The game concepts are way ahead of it's time, and the way you have to manage you're Civ matters more than any soldier. Just opening the game and reading the Civ-pedia will leave you speechless with history lessons. I learned alot just by reading in-game. If you love prior Civ games before III, I reccomend you pick up this game and enjoy the good old days of Civ. This is the high point in Civ.
